standard_metadata.standard_description: Verify experimentally the properties of rotations, reflections, and translations:

question.content: **What single transformation was applied to quadrilateral $A$ to get quadrilateral $B$?**

images.alt: Concave quadrilateral A has its concave part facing down and to the right and its point facing up and to the left. Concave quadrilateral B has its concave part facing down and to the left and its point facing up and to the right. In both quadrilaterals there is a larger angle and a smaller angle adjacent to the concave angle. In both quadrilaterals, the larger angle is above the smaller angle.

hints.content: - A *translation* moves a figure up, down, left, or right, or any combination of those. - A *rotation* turns a figure around a single point, either on or off of the figure. - A *reflection* makes a mirror image of a figure across an imaginary line. - A *dilation* enlarges or shrinks a figure.

For this figure, we can visualize a line between quadrilateral $A$ and quadrilateral $B$ such that each point in quadrilateral $B$ is the same distance from the line, but on the opposite side, as the corresponding point in quadrilateral $A$.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Concave quadrilateral A and concave quadrilateral B. A is reflected over a vertical line to form B. There is a ray from each vertex to the line of reflection to show equal distance of each ray for corresponding vertices.

hints.content: We apply a *reflection* to quadrilateral $A$ to get quadrilateral $B$.

question.content: **What single transformation was applied to quadrilateral $A$ to get quadrilateral $B$?**

images.alt: An image labeled B and pre-image labeled A of the same quadrilateral. A vertex of the pre-image is at 12 o clock and moves to 2 o clock on the image. Another vertex is at 7 o clock and moves to 9 o clock.

hints.content: - A *translation* moves a figure up, down, left, or right, or any combination of those. - A *rotation* turns a figure around a single point, either on or off of the figure. - A *reflection* makes a mirror image of a figure across an imaginary line. - A *dilation* enlarges or shrinks a figure.
For this figure, we can imagine holding a pencil on the paper near quadrilateral $A$ and turning the paper until quadrilateral $A$ overlaps quadrilateral $B$.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: An image labeled B and pre-image labeled A of the same quadrilateral. A vertex of the pre-image is at 12 o clock and moves to 2 o clock on the image with an arrow curving from the pre-image's vertex to its corresponding vertex in the image. Another vertex is at 7 o clock and moves to 9 o clock with an arrow curving from that pre-image vertex to the image vertex. A point, where the pencil tip can be placed is to the bottom left of the pre-image.

hints.content: We apply a *rotation* to quadrilateral $A$ to get quadrilateral $B$.

question.content: **What single transformation was applied to triangle $A$ to get triangle $B$?**

images.alt: A triangle pre-image labeled A and its image of the similar triangle but smaller labeled B.

hints.content: - A *translation* moves a figure up, down, left, or right, or any combination of those. - A *rotation* turns a figure around a single point, either on or off of the figure. - A *reflection* makes a mirror image of a figure across an imaginary line. - A *dilation* enlarges or shrinks a figure.
Since triangle $B$ is smaller, but has the exact same shape and direction as triangle $A$, we have shrunk triangle $A$ to get triangle $B$.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Triangle A and triangle B. Triangle A is larger than triangle B. There is a point above triangle B. There are rays from the vertices of triangle A through the vertices of triangle B that intersect at the point above triangle B.

hints.content: We apply a *dilation* to triangle $A$ to get triangle $B$.

question.content: **What single transformation was applied to quadrilateral $A$ to get quadrilateral $B$?**

images.alt: A quadrilateral pre-image labeled A and its image of the similar quadrilateral but larger labeled B.

hints.content: - A *translation* moves a figure up, down, left, or right, or any combination of those. - A *rotation* turns a figure around a single point, either on or off of the figure. - A *reflection* makes a mirror image of a figure across an imaginary line. - A *dilation* enlarges or shrinks a figure.
Since quadrilateral $B$ is larger, but has the exact same shape and direction as quadrilateral $A$, we have enlarged quadrilateral $A$ to get quadrilateral $B$.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A quadrilateral pre-image labeled A and its image of the similar quadrilateral but larger labeled B. 4 lines pass stem from a point in the top left of the quadrilaterals where each line passes through quadrilateral A and B corresponding vertices.

hints.content: We apply a *dilation* to quadrilateral $A$ to get quadrilateral $B$.

question.content: **What single transformation was applied to triangle $A$ to get triangle $B$?**

images.alt: A triangle labeled A and a congruent triangle labeled B. Triangle B faces the opposite way than triangle A.

hints.content: - A *translation* moves a figure up, down, left, or right, or any combination of those. - A *rotation* turns a figure around a single point, either on or off of the figure. - A *reflection* makes a mirror image of a figure across an imaginary line. - A *dilation* enlarges or shrinks a figure.
For this figure, we can imagine holding a pencil on the paper near triangle $A$ and turning the paper until triangle $A$ overlaps triangle $B$.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A triangle labeled A and a congruent triangle labeled B. Triangle B faces the opposite way than triangle A. Arrows point from the three vertices in triangle A to their corresponding vertices in triangle B.

hints.content: We apply a *rotation* to triangle $A$ to get triangle $B$.

question.content: **What single transformation was applied to triangle $A$ to get triangle $B$?**

images.alt: A triangle labeled A and a congruent triangle labeled B. Triangle B faces the opposite way than triangle A.

hints.content: - A *translation* moves a figure up, down, left, or right, or any combination of those. - A *rotation* turns a figure around a single point, either on or off of the figure. - A *reflection* makes a mirror image of a figure across an imaginary line. - A *dilation* enlarges or shrinks a figure.

For this figure, we can visualize a line between triangle $A$ and triangle $B$ such that each point in triangle $B$ is the same distance from the line, but on the opposite side, as the corresponding point in triangle $A$.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A triangle labeled A and a congruent triangle labeled B. Triangle B faces the opposite way than triangle A. A dashed line slants down from left to right evenly separating the triangles. Arrows point from corresponding vertices of both triangles to the dashed line.

hints.content: We apply a *reflection* to triangle $A$ to get triangle $B$.

question.content: **What single transformation was applied to quadrilateral $A$ to get quadrilateral $B$?**

images.alt: A quadrilateral labeled A and a quadrilateral labeled B that is the same size, shape, and position as quadrilateral A just moved down and to the left.

hints.content: - A *translation* moves a figure up, down, left, or right, or any combination of those. - A *rotation* turns a figure around a single point, either on or off of the figure. - A *reflection* makes a mirror image of a figure across an imaginary line. - A *dilation* enlarges or shrinks a figure.
We can move quadrilateral $A$ down and left so that each point on quadrilateral $A$ corresponds with a point on quadrilateral $B$.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Quadrilateral A is above and to the right of quadrilateral B. There are rays from each vertex in quadrilateral A to each corresponding vertex in quadrilateral B

hints.content: We apply a *translation* to quadrilateral $A$ to get quadrilateral $B$.

question.content: **What single transformation was applied to triangle $A$ to get triangle $B$?**

images.alt: A right triangle labeled A and a right triangle labeled B that is the same size, shape, and position as triangle A just moved up and to the right.

hints.content: - A *translation* moves a figure up, down, left, or right, or any combination of those. - A *rotation* turns a figure around a single point, either on or off of the figure. - A *reflection* makes a mirror image of a figure across an imaginary line. - A *dilation* enlarges or shrinks a figure.
We can move triangle $A$ up and right so that each point on triangle $A$ corresponds with a point on triangle $B$.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A right triangle labeled A and a right triangle labeled B that is the same size, shape, and position as triangle A just moved up and to the right. An arrow points from each vertex of triangle A to each corresponding vertex of triangle B.

hints.content: We apply a *translation* to triangle $A$ to get triangle $B$.

question.content: **What single transformation was applied to triangle $A$ to get triangle $B$?**

images.alt: A coordinate plane where a right triangle labeled A and a right triangle labeled B that is the same size, shape, and position as triangle A just moved down four units and to the right three units.

hints.content: - A *translation* moves a figure up, down, left, or right, or any combination of those. - A *rotation* turns a figure around a single point, either on or off of the figure. - A *reflection* makes a mirror image of a figure across an imaginary line. - A *dilation* enlarges or shrinks a figure.
We can move triangle $A$ down and right so that each point on triangle $A$ corresponds with a point on triangle $B$.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A coordinate plane where a right triangle labeled A and a right triangle labeled B that is the same size, shape, and position as triangle A just moved down four and to the right three. An arrow points from each vertex of triangle A to each corresponding vertex of triangle B.

hints.content: We apply a *translation* to triangle $A$ to get triangle $B$.

question.content: **What single transformation was applied to quadrilateral $A$ to get quadrilateral $B$?**

images.alt: A coordinate plane where quadrilaterals A and B are located. Both quadrilaterals are the same size and shape. Quadrilateral B has a vertex that is at 12 o clock, while quadrilateral A has its corresponding vertex at 3 o clock.

hints.content: - A *translation* moves a figure up, down, left, or right, or any combination of those. - A *rotation* turns a figure around a single point, either on or off of the figure. - A *reflection* makes a mirror image of a figure across an imaginary line. - A *dilation* enlarges or shrinks a figure.
For this figure, we can imagine holding a pencil on the paper near quadrilateral $A$ and turning the paper until quadrilateral $A$ overlaps quadrilateral $B$.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A coordinate plane where quadrilaterals A and B are located. Both quadrilaterals are the same size and shape. Quadrilateral B has a vertex that is at 12 o clock, while quadrilateral A has its corresponding vertex at 3 o clock. An arrown curves from each vertex in quadrilateral A to each corresponding vertex in quadrilateral B. A point for a pencil tip is located beneath the quadrilateral B.

hints.content: We apply a *rotation* to quadrilateral $A$ to get quadrilateral $B$.

question.content: **What single transformation was applied to triangle $A$ to get triangle $B$?**

images.alt: A coordinate plane with congruent triangles labeled A and B. Triangle A has a vertex at 1 o clock and the corresponding vertex on B is at 7 o clock.

hints.content: - A *translation* moves a figure up, down, left, or right, or any combination of those. - A *rotation* turns a figure around a single point, either on or off of the figure. - A *reflection* makes a mirror image of a figure across an imaginary line. - A *dilation* enlarges or shrinks a figure.
For this figure, we can imagine holding a pencil on the paper near triangle $A$ and turning the paper until triangle $A$ overlaps triangle $B$.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A coordinate plane with congruent triangles labeled A and B. Triangle A has a vertex at 1 o clock and the corresponding vertex on B is at 7 o clock. A point for a pencil tip is placed between the two triangles. An arrow points from each of the vertices of triangle A to their corresponding vertices of triangle B.

hints.content: We apply a *rotation* to triangle $A$ to get triangle $B$.

question.content: **What single transformation was applied to quadrilateral $A$ to get quadrilateral $B$?**

images.alt: A coordinate plane with 2 quadrilaterals labeled A and B. They are similar but quadrilateral B is larger than quadrilateral A.

hints.content: - A *translation* moves a figure up, down, left, or right, or any combination of those. - A *rotation* turns a figure around a single point, either on or off of the figure. - A *reflection* makes a mirror image of a figure across an imaginary line. - A *dilation* enlarges or shrinks a figure.
Since quadrilateral $B$ is larger, but has the exact same shape and direction as quadrilateral $A$, we have enlarged quadrilateral $A$ to get quadrilateral $B$.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A coordinate plane with 2 quadrilaterals labeled A and B. They are similar but quadrilateral B is larger than quadrilateral A. A point to the bottom left of the two quadrilaterals have arrows pointing from the point to the verticies of quadrilateral A. Quadrilateral A has arrow pointing from its vertices to the corresponding vertices in quadrilateral B.

hints.content: We apply a *dilation* to quadrilateral $A$ to get quadrilateral $B$.

question.content: **What single transformation was applied to triangle $A$ to get triangle $B$?**

images.alt: A coordinate plane with 2 triangles labeled A and B. They are similar but triangle B is smaller than triangle A.

hints.content: - A *translation* moves a figure up, down, left, or right, or any combination of those. - A *rotation* turns a figure around a single point, either on or off of the figure. - A *reflection* makes a mirror image of a figure across an imaginary line. - A *dilation* enlarges or shrinks a figure.
Since triangle $B$ is smaller, but has the exact same shape and direction as triangle $A$, we have shrunk triangle $A$ to get triangle $B$.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A coordinate plane with 2 triangles labeled A and B. They are similar, but triangle B is smaller than triangle A. A point is at the top right of the two triangles and has arrows pointing from the vertices of triangle A to the corresponging vertices of triangle B. Arrows from the vertices of triangle B are all pointing to that one point.

hints.content: We apply a *dilation* to triangle $A$ to get triangle $B$.

question.content: **What single transformation was applied to triangle $A$ to get triangle $B$?**

images.alt: A coordinate plane with 2 triangles labeled A and B. They are congruent but their corrsponding vertices are opposite of one another.

hints.content: - A *translation* moves a figure up, down, left, or right, or any combination of those. - A *rotation* turns a figure around a single point, either on or off of the figure. - A *reflection* makes a mirror image of a figure across an imaginary line. - A *dilation* enlarges or shrinks a figure.

For this figure, we can visualize a line between triangle $A$ and triangle $B$ such that each point in triangle $B$ is the same distance from the line, but on the opposite side, as the corresponding point in triangle $A$.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A coordinate plane with 2 triangles labeled A and B. They are congruent but their corrsponding vertices are opposite of one another. A vertical dashed line evenly divides between the two triangles. Arrows from the vertices of both triangles point to the vertical dashed line.

hints.content: We apply a *reflection* to triangle $A$ to get triangle $B$.

question.content: **What single transformation was applied to quadrilateral $A$ to get quadrilateral $B$?**

images.alt: A coordinate plane with 2 quadrilaterals labeled A and B. They are congruent but quadrilateral B is flipped both down and to the right.

hints.content: - A *translation* moves a figure up, down, left, or right, or any combination of those. - A *rotation* turns a figure around a single point, either on or off of the figure. - A *reflection* makes a mirror image of a figure across an imaginary line. - A *dilation* enlarges or shrinks a figure.

For this figure, we can visualize a line between quadrilateral $A$ and quadrilateral $B$ such that each point in quadrilateral $B$ is the same distance from the line, but on the opposite side, as the corresponding point in quadrilateral $A$.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A coordinate plane with 2 quadrilaterals labeled A and B. They are congruent but quadrilateral B is flipped both down and to the right. A dashed line slants up from left to right dividing evenly between the two quadrilaterals. An arrow from each of the corresponding vertices points to the dashed line.

hints.content: We apply a *reflection* to quadrilateral $A$ to get quadrilateral $B$.

question.content: **What single transformation was applied to quadrilateral $A$ to get quadrilateral $B$?**

images.alt: A coordinate plane with 2 quadrilaterals labeled A and B. They are congruent but quadrilateral B up five units and to the left three units.

hints.content: - A *translation* moves a figure up, down, left, or right, or any combination of those. - A *rotation* turns a figure around a single point, either on or off of the figure. - A *reflection* makes a mirror image of a figure across an imaginary line. - A *dilation* enlarges or shrinks a figure.
We can move quadrilateral $A$ up and left so that each point on quadrilateral $A$ corresponds with a point on quadrilateral $B$.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A coordinate plane with 2 quadrilaterals labeled A and B. They are congruent but quadrilateral B up five units and to the left three units. Arrows point from the vertices of quadrilateral A up and to the left to the corresponding vertices of quaadrilateral B.

hints.content: We apply a *translation* to quadrilateral $A$ to get quadrilateral $B$.
